awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding insect diapause is essential for predicting when and where insect populations will be active and abundant. Diapause is an internally regulated dormant state that allows insects to "escape" during seasons, such as winter, when the environmental conditions are harsh and unsuitable or normal growth and activity.  Diapause is characterized by changes in development, metabolism, and environmental stress resistance. Although there have been studies that characterized physiological, biochemical, and molecular changes that occur during diapause, the understanding of diapause regulation is far from being complete.  This research will provide new information about how diapause is regulated by investigating how small noncoding RNA molecules (microRNAs), regulate diapause. This study will improve our understanding of this important adaptation to changing environmental conditions. This research also has the potential to provide new tools for managing medically and economically important insects. For example, if microRNA function in insect diapause can block or induce diapause entry at a time of year that would be detrimental for their continued survival. This research has the potential to provide novel therapies for human medical disorders, such as cancer and diabetes, which share common, microRNA-associated regulatory mechanisms in humans and insects. Finally, the project will also provide integrative training and mentoring opportunities for multiple undergraduate students, while also broadly disseminating the findings to the public via informal science education to school children and families.

Studying insect diapause provides a conceptual frame work for understanding how insects, and other animals, perceive environmental cues and translate them into phenotypic changes that allow them to survive biotic and abiotic challenges they encounter. MicroRNAs (miRNAs, ~22 nucleotide, noncoding RNAs) are evolutionarily conserved, regulatory molecules that have important roles in diapause-relevant biological processes (e.g. developmental arrest, metabolic repression, and stress-resistance) in evolutionarily diverse species. Numerous miRNAs are deferentially regulated during pupal diapause in the flesh fly, Sarcophaga bullata, but their functional relevance is currently unknown. The aim of this project is to identify, and experimentally validate, mRNA targets of diapause-relevant miRNAs using computational and biochemical approaches. Specifically, the project focuses on miRNA:mRNA pairs that may have a role in environmental stress-resistance, a defining feature of the diapause phenotype.  It also investigates the evolutionary context of miRNA:mRNA regulatory networks and their contribution to the diapause phenotype in multiple insect species. Together, the results from the proposed research are expected to provide an entirely new dimension to the understanding of insect diapause as well as insights concerning the evolutionary conservation of miRNA:mRNA interactions across Insecta.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Diapause is an internally regulated state of suspended animation (i.e., dormancy) that allows insects, and other animals, to survive seasons with of inhospitable environmental conditions. Diapause is an alternative developmental program that is initiated in response to changes in daylength, the availability of nutritious food, or other factors that indicate winter is coming.  Once detected, these diapause inducing-cues trigger changes in hormones and neuropeptides that, ultimately, lead to downstream changes in metabolic rate, developmental timing, and the ability to deal with environmental stress. Insects that enter diapause will remain dormant through the winter until a process known as diapause terminate occurs and allows normal biological processes to resume, weather permitting.

Numerous studies on a wide range of insects have revealed many of the processes that regulate diapause. Although scientist now know that diapause is regulated by networks of up- and downregulated genes, many details about how these networks are themselves regulated remain unknown. The overarching goal of the research funded by this grant was to improve our understanding of the gene regulatory networks that mediate diapause by focusing on the link between gene transcription and protein synthesis (i.e., translation). The research investigated the role of microRNAs, one class of small noncoding RNAs, that limit the number of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are ultimately used to synthesize protein. Specific objectives included 1) identifying the functional significance of microRNAs that are up- or downregulated during diapause in the corn earworm, Helicoverpa zea, a major agricultural pest in the United States; 2) characterizing microRNAs that regulate the transition from diapause to post-diapause quiescence in alfalfa leafcutting bees, Megachile rotundata, an important pollinator of alfalfa and other crops; and 3) discovering the role of microRNAs in the response to environmental stress in flesh flies, Sarcophaga bullata.

Intellectual Outcomes:

Outcomes from the research on Helicoverpa zea include the discovery of miRNA-regulated proteins that are fundamental for managing metabolism during diapause. microRNAs that were elevated during diapause target, and limit the synthesis of, proteins that transport sugars, salts, and amino acids throughout the cell. microRNA regulation of these proteins is important for turning down the energy consumed at a time when metabolic fuels are limited.

The research on H. zea also identified a microRNA-regulated enzyme that may potentially act as a master switch during diapause. Nemo-like kinase regulates multiple signaling pathways that, ultimately, regulate development, metabolism, and circadian rhythms. Ongoing research will characterize this little-studied protein, its role in diapause-relevant pathways, and its potential for manipulating diapause in economically and medically important insects.  

Outcomes from research on Megachile rotundata include a new understanding of the gene networks involved with diapause termination and post-diapause quiescence. Multiple microRNAs are elevated during the transition from diapause to post-diapause quiescence. The targets of these microRNAs include solute carriers and other proteins that regulate metabolism and development. Ongoing research will continue to uncover details about the function of these miRNAs during the transition from dormancy to active development.

Outcomes from research on Sarcophaga bullata suggests that microRNAs have a role in recovery from environmental stress, especially cold temperatures. Pupae of S. bullata overwinter underground where temperatures are often below freezing. There was no change in microRNA abundance that occurred while they were exposed to freezing temperatures, but multiple microRNAs were downregulated during the time flies were recovering from cold stress. Ongoing research will continue to discover the genes are regulated by these miRNAs and how they aid in recovery from cold exposure.

In summary, the research funded by this grant identified previously unexplored means of diapause regulation in agriculturally and economically important insects. These insights provide a foundation for further basic research on insects and diapause, but they also have the potential to form the basis of novel management strategies for economically important insects.

Broader Impacts Outcomes:

This grant include training for nine undergraduate students who have gone on to medical school, graduate school, or become leaders in biological research labs. The funding also provided opportunities for science communication and engagement training. Articles, blog posts, and presentations on topics related to the research, including stress tolerance and adaptation to novel environments, are well received by general public. These topics are also well suited for teaching science to religious communities. During the grant period, 16 pieces on diapause, maternal effects, epigenetics, and adaptation were published by Christan organizations. In addition, multiple research-related presentations given to religious audiences, and four presentations were given on aspects of science and religious faith. Taken together, these written pieces and presentations provided a gateway for discussing evolution and similar subjects with religious groups that may otherwise be reluctant to engage with ideas considered to be controversial.
